member.name: T:Java.Interop.IJavaPeerable
member.summary: Support for using Java object instances.

remarks.para: The IJavaPeerable interface provides access to a Java object instance, invocation of members on that Java instance, control over the lifetime of that object instance, and callbacks for when the wrapper is being disposed or finalized. The following operations are permitted:

item.term:
Object instance access is available through the
property.

Member access and invocation is available through the
property.

Object lifetime control through and
methods.
Disposal and finalization callbacks through the and methods.

block.para:
Implementations of this interface are useless without a
implementation which returns a non-default(JniObjectReference) value, which corresponds to in the Java VM. While this can be done, it frequently isn't, resulting in "unexpected" NullPointerException errors from Java. Additionally, even though you can implement PeerReference, any implementation won't fit in with a garbage collector, resulting in either memory leaks or additional work to clean values up.

member.name: P:Java.Interop.IJavaPeerable.JniIdentityHashCode
member.summary: Returns the value of java.lang.System.identityHashCode() for the wrapped instance.

remarks.block: This property will not throw a after the instance has been disposed.
The JniIdentityHashCode property should return the value last passed to .

member.name: M:Java.Interop.IJavaPeerable.SetJniIdentityHashCode(System.Int32)
member.summary: Set the value returned by JniIdentityHashCode.
member.param:
A which contains the value that future invocations of the
property should return.

remarks.para:
The SetJniIdentityHashCode method is invoked to alter the value returned by future access to the
property.
remarks.block: This method should only be invoked by the instance which will be managing the IJavaPeerable value.

member.name: P:Java.Interop.IJavaPeerable.PeerReference
member.summary: Returns a of the wrapped Java object instance.

remarks.block: This property will not throw a after the instance has been disposed.

block.para: THIS VALUE WILL CHANGE OVER TIME. It is NOT stable. It may potentially change during any future GC. DO NOT use this value as a key in a dictionary. The property may be used for that purpose.
While the value can change, the PeerReference property should always refer to the same Java instance. (Multiple different JNI handle values may refer to the same Java instance.)

remarks.block: The JniIdentityHashCode property should return the value last passed to .

member.name: M:Java.Interop.IJavaPeerable.SetPeerReference(Java.Interop.JniObjectReference)
member.summary: Set the value returned by PeerReference.
member.param:
A which contains the value that future invocations of the
property should return.

remarks.para:
The SetPeerReference method is invoked to alter the value returned by future access to the
property.
remarks.block: This method should only be invoked by the instance which will be managing the IJavaPeerable value.

member.name: P:Java.Interop.IJavaPeerable.JniPeerMembers
member.summary: Member access and invocation support.

remarks.block: This property will not throw a after the instance has been disposed.

block.para: The JniPeerMembers property may be accessed before the constructor has executed, as common behavior is for the JniPeerMembers to be access virtually to permit caching of constructor jmethodIDs.

member.name: P:Java.Interop.IJavaPeerable.JniManagedPeerState
member.summary: State of the managed peer.

remarks.para:
A value providing the state of the current Managed Peer instance.
(Definitions)

member.name: M:Java.Interop.IJavaPeerable.UnregisterFromRuntime
member.summary:
Unregister this instance so that the runtime will not return it from future
invocations.

remarks.para:
Call this method when you would like to prevent this instance from being returned by future
invocations.

member.name: M:Java.Interop.IJavaPeerable.DisposeUnlessReferenced
member.summary: If there are no outstanding references to this instance, then calls Dispose(); otherwise, does nothing.

remarks.para: Call this method when you would like to allow instances to be collectable as soon as possible, but not if the current instance is referenced anywhere else.
remarks.block: "not referenced anywhere else" may mean "is not registered".

member.name: M:Java.Interop.IJavaPeerable.Disposed
member.summary: Called when the instance has been disposed.

remarks.para: The Disposed method is invoked after the method has been invoked on the instance. The property is still valid when Disposed is invoked.
remarks.block: This method should only be invoked by the instance which will be managing the IJavaPeerable value.

block.para: If the type is following the typical IDisposable pattern, then the Disposed method should delegate to the Dispose(bool) method. The proscribed implementation template is:

member.name: M:Java.Interop.IJavaPeerable.Finalized
member.summary: Called when the instance has been finalized.

remarks.para: The Finalized method is invoked after the finalizer has been invoked on the instance. The property is NOT valid when Finalized is invoked.
remarks.block: This method should only be invoked by the instance which will be managing the IJavaPeerable value.

block.para: If the type is following the typical IDisposable pattern, then the Finalized method should delegate to the Dispose(bool) method. The proscribed implementation template is:

member.name: T:Java.Interop.JniEnvironment.References
member.summary: JNI Reference-related functionality.

remarks.para: The JniEnvironment.References class exposes JNI Global, Local, Weak-Global-related functionality which is not exposed by the class, particularly JNI reference creation and destruction.

member.name: M:Java.Interop.JniEnvironment.References.CreatedReference(Java.Interop.JniObjectReference)
member.summary: Account for the creation of a JNI Reference.
member.param: A value containing a JNI Reference that was created.
member.exception: is not a JNI Local Reference.

remarks.para:
The property provides an advisory value of the number of JNI Local References which Java.Interop has created. The
property provides an advisory value of the number of JNI Global References which Java.Interop has created. The
property contains an advisory value of the number of JNI Weak Global References which Java.Interop has created. These counts are incremented whenever a JNI reference is created, e.g. from or , and this count is decremented whenever a JNI Local Reference is destroyed, e.g. from .

This accounting assumes a worldview in which Java.Interop can intervene wherever a JNI Local Reference can be created. This is not the case, as there are some scenarios where JNI Local References can be created without Java.Interop knowing about it. One such notable example is when using Platform Invoke to invoke a native Java_ C function which returns a JNI Local Reference (). When such untrackable JNI Local References are created, this may result in future assertions failing within
when the tracked JNI Local Reference count becomes negative.
Use the CreatedLocalReference to notify Java.Interop that a JNI Local Reference has been created externally, so that the JNI Local Reference accounting doesn't generate future assertions.

member.name: T:Java.Interop.JavaPeerableExtensions
member.summary: Extension methods on .

member.name: M:Java.Interop.JavaPeerableExtensions.GetJniTypeName(Java.Interop.IJavaPeerable)
member.summary: Gets the JNI name of the type of the instance .
member.param: The instance to get the JNI type name of.

remarks.para: The JNI type name is the name of the Java type, as it would be used in Java Native Interface (JNI) API calls. For example, instead of the Java name java.lang.Object, the JNI name is java/lang/Object.

member.name: M:Java.Interop.JavaPeerableExtensions.TryJavaCast``1(Java.Interop.IJavaPeerable,``0@)
member.param: A instance to coerce to type .
When this method returns, contains a value of type if can be coerced to the Java type corresponding to , or null if the coercion is not valid.
member.summary: Try to coerce to type , checking that the coercion is valid on the Java side.

remarks.block: Implementations of consist of two halves: a Java peer and a managed peer. The property associates the managed peer to the Java peer.
The or custom attributes are used to associated a managed type to a Java type.

exception.para: The Java peer type for could not be found.
The type or a Invoker type for does not provide an activation constructor, a constructor with a singature of (ref JniObjectReference, JniObjectReferenceOptions) or (IntPtr, JniHandleOwnership).

member.param: A instance to coerce to type .
member.summary: Try to coerce to type , checking that the coercion is valid on the Java side.
member.returns: A value of type if the Java peer to can be coerced to the Java type corresponding to ; otherwise, null.

remarks.block: Implementations of consist of two halves: a Java peer and a managed peer. The property associates the managed peer to the Java peer.
The or custom attributes are used to associated a managed type to a Java type.

exception.para: The Java peer type for could not be found.
The type or a Invoker type for does not provide an activation constructor, a constructor with a singature of (ref JniObjectReference, JniObjectReferenceOptions) or (IntPtr, JniHandleOwnership).

member.name: T:Java.Interop.JniManagedPeerStates
member.summary: Managed peer states.

member.name: F:Java.Interop.JniManagedPeerStates.Activatable
member.summary: Managed peer is eligeable for activation.

remarks.para: A managed peer is activatable if it the native peer was constructed first and a forthcoming constructor invocation is assumed to be forthcoming.

member.name: F:Java.Interop.JniManagedPeerStates.Replaceable
member.summary: Managed peer is replaceable.

remarks.para: A managed peer is replaceable if it was created through . Being "replaceable" means that if another peer instance is created around the same Java instance, the newly created instance will replace the replaceable peer in the Java-to-managed instance mapping.
